January 27, 2013: Fiction
A MEMORY OF LIGHT, by Robert Jordan and Brandon Sanderson. (Tor/Tom
Doherty, $34.99.) The 14th and final novel in the Wheel of Time fantasy series.
GONE GIRL, by Gillian Flynn. (Crown, $25.) A woman disappears on her fifth
anniversary; is her husband a killer?
TENTH OF DECEMBER, by George Saunders. (Random House, $26.) Stories that
take on the big questions.
KINSEY AND ME, by Sue Grafton. (Marian Wood/Putnam, $27.95.) Stories about
Grafton’s character Kinsey Millhone as well as explorations of Grafton’s own past.
COLLATERAL DAMAGE, by Stuart Woods. (Putnam, $26.95.) Back in New York, the
lawyer Stone Barrington joins his former partner Holly Barker in pursuing a dangerous
case.
THE HUSBAND LIST, by Janet Evanovich. (St. Martin's, $27.99.) In New York City in
1894, a wealthy young woman yearns for adventure and the love of an Irish-American
with new money, rather than the titled Britons to whom her mother hopes to marry her
off.
THE TWELVE TRIBES OF HATTIE, by Ayana Mathis. (Knopf, $24.95.) Fifty-some
years in the life of an African-American family whose matriarch arrives in Philadelphia
THE BLOOD GOSPEL, by James Rollins and Rebecca Cantrell.
(Morrow/HarperCollins, $27.99.) A hunt for the truth about a shadowy ancient order
and a book supposed to have been written in Christ’s own hand and in his blood; the
first book in a series, the Order of the Sanguines.
THE RACKETEER, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $28.95.) An imprisoned ex-lawyer
schemes to exchange information about a murdered federal judge for his freedom.
DREAM EYES, by Jayne Ann Krentz. (Putnam, $26.95.) A psychic counselor,
returning to a small Oregon town after her mentor’s suspicious death, is drawn to a
psychic investigator with disturbing power; a Dark Legacy novel.
1356, by Bernard Cornwell. (Harper/HarperCollins, $28.99.) In the fourth book of the
Grail Quest series, the English and French face off at the Battle of Poitiers.
THE FORGOTTEN, by David Baldacci. (Grand Central, $27.99.) The military
investigator John Puller, the protagonist of “Zero Day,” probes his aunt’s mysterious
death in Florida.
CROSS ROADS, by Wm. Paul Young. (FaithWords, $24.99.) A comatose
businessman encounters Jesus, the Holy Spirit and God; from the author of “The
Shack.”
January 27, 2013
Non-Fiction
KILLING KENNEDY, by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard. (Holt, $28.) The host of
“The O’Reilly Factor” recounts the events surrounding the assassination of John F.
Kennedy.
MY SHARE OF THE TASK, by Stanley McChrystal. (Portfolio/Penguin, $29.95.)
The former commander of U.S. forces in Afghanistan, now retired, reviews his
career.
NO EASY DAY, by Mark Owen with Kevin Maurer. (Dutton, $26.95.) An account
by a former member of the Navy SEALs, written pseudonymously, of the mission
that killed bin Laden.
THOMAS JEFFERSON, by Jon Meacham. (Random House, $35.) The Pulitzer
Prize-winning biographer celebrates Jefferson’s skills as a practical politician.
THE WORLD UNTIL YESTERDAY, by Jared Diamond. (Viking, $36.) The author
of “Guns, Germs, and Steel” examines what we can learn from traditional
societies.
KILLING LINCOLN, by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard. (Holt, $28.) The host of
"The O'Reilly Factor" recounts the events surrounding the assassination of
Abraham Lincoln.
THE DUDE AND THE ZEN MASTER, by Jeff Bridges and Bernie Glassman. (Blue
Rider, $26.95.) The actor and the Zen master, longtime friends, examine the
wisdom of Bridges’s character the Dude from the 1998 cult classic “The Big
Lebowski.”
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $27.) An Olympic runner's
story of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
BEHIND THE BEAUTIFUL FOREVERS, by Katherine Boo. (Random House, $27.)
A journalist reports on families striving for better lives in a Mumbai slum.
THE POWER OF HABIT, by Charles Duhigg. (Random House, $28.) A Times
reporter’s account of the science behind how we form, and break, habits.
A HIGHER CALL, by Adam Makos with Larry Alexander. (Berkley Caliber,
$26.95.) An encounter between two pilots, an American and a German, in the
skies over Germany in December 1943.
WILD, by Cheryl Strayed. (Knopf, $25.95.) A woman's account of a life-changing
1,100-mile hike along the Pacific Crest Trail in the summer of 1995.
THE SIGNAL AND THE NOISE, by Nate Silver. (Penguin Press, $27.95.) An
examination of predictions, the ones that come true and the ones that don’t.
